Literature Review: Label-free electrochemical biosensing has emerged as a pivotal technology in the realm of disease detection, offering a blend of sensitivity, specificity, and practicality that is hard to match with traditional methods. This literature review delves into the mechanisms underpinning label-free electrochemical biosensing, recent advancements, and the integration of multiplex analysis and machine learning to enhance diagnostic capabilities. The four primary mechanisms identified include blocking the electrode surface, allowing greater access to the electrode surface, changing the intercalation or electrostatic affinity of a redox probe to a biorecognition unit, and modulating ion or electron transport properties due to conformational and surface charge changes. Each mechanism offers unique advantages and challenges, which are discussed in detail. Blocking the electrode surface, for instance, is a straightforward approach that can significantly enhance sensitivity by preventing non-specific binding, yet it may also limit the dynamic range of detection. Allowing greater access to the electrode surface, on the other hand, can improve the detection of larger analytes but may require more complex electrode designs. Changing the intercalation or electrostatic affinity of a redox probe allows for highly specific detection of target molecules, though it may necessitate the use of specialized redox probes. Modulating ion or electron transport properties offers a versatile approach to detecting a wide range of analytes, but it may be more susceptible to interference from environmental factors. Recent advancements in label-free electrochemical biosensing have focused on improving the sensitivity, selectivity, and stability of these mechanisms, as well as on integrating them with other technologies to create more powerful diagnostic tools. Multiplex analysis, for example, allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple analytes, greatly enhancing the efficiency and comprehensiveness of disease detection. Incorporating machine learning algorithms can further improve the accuracy and reliability of biosensors by enabling the analysis of complex data sets and the identification of subtle patterns that may be indicative of disease. Despite these advancements, challenges remain, including the need for further miniaturization and cost reduction, as well as the development of more robust and user-friendly biosensing platforms. Nonetheless, the potential of label-free electrochemical biosensing in disease detection is undeniable, and ongoing research and development efforts are likely to yield even more innovative and effective solutions in the near future.
